importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, reflecting the most recent Sunday's NFL Week 7 action, highlights the ongoing season progression and real-time updates on team performances and records.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame covers the first seven weeks of the 2025 NFL season, emphasizing a period of dramatic unpredictability, including numerous comeback victories and quarterback changes.

keyTakeAways: The NFL season has seen an unprecedented number of lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation, with 26 such changes in Week 7 alone — the most in NFL history over that span.
Denver Broncos became the first team since 2007 to overcome a 19-point deficit after leading by 18 points in the first three quarters, marking a historic comeback.
Second-year QB Bo Nix led a dramatic fourth-quarter surge, throwing two TDs and rushing for two scores, and completed a game-winning field goal as time expired.

Drake Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record for completion percentage (88.5%) with a 91.3% completion rate in a 31-13 win over the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era history to complete 90% of passes, throw for over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in a single game.

The Miami Dolphins and New York Jets were both defeated, leading to quarterback benchings: Tua Tagovailoa was replaced by rookie Quinn Ewers in Miami; Justin Fields was benched at halftime in New York and replaced by Tyrod Taylor.
The Green Bay Packers’ defense, led by Micah Parsons, dominated the Arizona Cardinals, forcing a late turnover and securing a 27-23 win.
The article highlights the volatility and unpredictability of the NFL season, where late comebacks and coaching decisions define the outcomes of games.

namedEntities.name: Bo Nix
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Second-year quarterback for the Denver Broncos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bo Nix led a historic comeback against the New York Giants, throwing two touchdowns and rushing for two scores in the fourth quarter, ultimately leading the Broncos to a 33-32 victory after being down by 19 points.

namedEntities.name: Drake Maye
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Quarterback for the New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise completion record with a 91.3% completion rate in a 31-13 win over the Tennessee Titans, marking a pivotal moment in the Patriots’ rebuild and signaling a new era of quarterback excellence.

namedEntities.name: Tom Brady
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former New England Patriots quarterback
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tom Brady’s franchise completion record of 88.5% (set in 2009) was broken by Drake Maye, highlighting a shift in quarterback performance standards and the evolving nature of offensive play in the NFL.

namedEntities.name: Tua Tagovailoa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Quarterback for the Miami Dolphins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tagovailoa had a poor performance with three interceptions in a loss to the Cleveland Browns, leading to his benching in favor of rookie Quinn Ewers.

namedEntities.name: Justin Fields
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Quarterback for the New York Jets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Fields struggled in the first half of a loss to the Carolina Panthers, leading to his benching at halftime and replacement by Tyrod Taylor.

namedEntities.name: Quinn Ewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Seventh-round rookie quarterback for the Miami Dolphins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ewers stepped in for Tua Tagovailoa in the fourth quarter of a game against the Cleveland Browns, becoming the first rookie to take over during a critical game in a high-pressure situation.

namedEntities.name: Tyrod Taylor
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Backup quarterback for the New York Jets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Taylor replaced Justin Fields in the second half and helped the Jets move the ball, though he threw two costly interceptions in a loss to the Panthers.

namedEntities.name: Micah Parsons
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Defensive end for the Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Parsons was a key defensive force, recording his third sack of the game against the Arizona Cardinals and disrupting their final drive, contributing to a 27-23 win for the Packers.

namedEntities.name: Jacoby Brissett
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Backup quarterback for the Arizona Cardinals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brissett led a late drive in the final minutes against the Packers, but was disrupted by Micah Parsons and the Packers' defense, resulting in a 27-23 loss.

namedEntities.name: Mike Vrabel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head coach of the New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vrabel returned to the Patriots after being fired by the Tennessee Titans, and won his first game against the Patriots, symbolizing a team-wide shift in culture and coaching success.

namedEntities.name: Head Coach Aaron Glenn
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head coach of the New York Jets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Glenn made the decision to bench Justin Fields at halftime, citing a need for a 'spark' in the offense, which reflects the pressure on coaching decisions during a losing season.

namedEntities.name: New England Patriots
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in New England
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Patriots are in transition, with Drake Maye emerging as a star quarterback, marking a new era after Tom Brady’s departure.

namedEntities.name: Denver Broncos
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Denver
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit after leading by 18 points in the first three quarters, the first such instance in NFL history.

namedEntities.name: Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Green Bay
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Packers won a close game against the Arizona Cardinals, with key defensive contributions from Micah Parsons and a late-game touchdown.

namedEntities.name: Miami Dolphins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Miami
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dolphins suffered a devastating loss to the Cleveland Browns, leading to the immediate benching of Tua Tagovailoa and a shift in team momentum.

namedEntities.name: New York Jets
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in New York
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Jets remain winless (0-7) after a loss to the Carolina Panthers, with quarterback Justin Fields benched and the team facing significant offensive struggles.

namedEntities.name: Cleveland Browns
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Cleveland
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Browns defeated the Miami Dolphins 31-6, marking a critical win in the AFC East and highlighting the team's growing competitiveness.

namedEntities.name: Carolina Panthers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Carolina
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Panthers defeated the New York Jets 13-6, and lost starting QB Bryce Young to injury, yet managed a first road win of the season.

namedEntities.name: Tennessee Titans
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Tennessee
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Titans lost to the New England Patriots 13-31, showcasing a poor performance despite having a strong defensive effort.

namedEntities.name: Arizona Cardinals
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Arizona
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Cardinals lost to the Green Bay Packers 23-27, with backup quarterback Jacoby Brissett struggling under defensive pressure.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Rams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Los Angeles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Rams played in London and lost to the Jacksonville Jaguars 35-7, signaling a challenge in their international schedule.

namedEntities.name: Jacksonville Jaguars
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Jacksonville
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Jaguars lost to the Los Angeles Rams in London, marking a significant setback in their season.

namedEntities.name: Chicago Bears
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Chicago
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bears defeated the New Orleans Saints 26-14, showing strong offensive performance.

namedEntities.name: Kansas City Chiefs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Kansas City

namedEntities.name: Minnesota Vikings
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Minnesota

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Chargers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team based in Los Angeles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Chargers lost to the Indianapolis Colts 24-38, showing a decline in offensive consistency.

namedEntities.name: Dallas Cowboys

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Cowboys defeated the Washington Commanders 44-22, showcasing a dominant performance and a strong start to their season.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 49ers defeated the Atlanta Falcons 20-10, highlighting a balanced and effective performance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season was defined by dramatic late comebacks, historic performances, and high-stakes quarterback changes. The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit to defeat the New York Giants, with second-year QB Bo Nix leading a fourth-quarter surge. In a separate game, New England Patriots' quarterback Drake Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise completion record (88.5%) with a 91.3% completion rate, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era history to complete 90% of passes, throw for over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in one game. Meanwhile, the Miami Dolphins and New York Jets suffered devastating losses, prompting immediate benchings: Tua Tagovailoa was replaced by rookie Quinn Ewers in Miami, and Justin Fields was benched at halftime in New York after a poor first half. The Green Bay Packers also secured a narrow win over the Arizona Cardinals, fueled by defensive dominance from Micah Parsons. The season continues to reflect a high level of unpredictability, with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes — the most in NFL history — illustrating the volatility and emotional intensity of the league.
title: Historic and dramatic comebacks, second-year QB breaks Tom Brady record and high-profile benchings: NFL Week 7 Sunday review
